sen.j: 甲斐庄（荘）氏（かいのしょうし／かいしょうし）は日本の氏族の一つ。
sen.e: The Kainosho clan is one of the Japanese clans.
The Kainosho clan was one of Japan's clans.
The Kainosho clan was one of Japan's clans.

sen.j: 楠木正成の弟楠木正季の子孫が河内国錦織郡甲斐庄を領有し、甲斐庄を名乗ったことに由来する。
sen.e: The name originates from the fact that Masashige KUSUNOKI's younger brother, Masasue KUSUNOKI's descendants occupied Kainosho in Nishikiori County, Kawachi Province.
The name originates from the fact that the descendants of Masashige KUSUNOKI's younger brother, Masasue KUSUNOKI, ruled Kainosho in Nishikiori County, Kawachi Province.
The name originates from the fact that the descendants of Masashige KUSUNOKI's younger brother, Masasue KUSUNOKI, ruled Kainosho in Nishikiori County, Kawachi Province.

sen.j: 楠木氏の一族ではあるが、室町時代に河内守護であった畠山氏に降伏し、その家臣となり、本領安堵された。
sen.e: They originate from the Kusunoki clan, but after surrendering to the Hatayama clan who were the Kawachi Shugo (the provincial constable of Kawachi Province), the Kainosho clan became their vassal and was approved of its main domain.

They were originally part of the Kusunoki clan, but after surrendering to the Hatayama clan, whose leader was the Shugo (military governor) for Kawachi Province, they became vassals of the Hatayama clan and were allowed to keep their main domain as their fiefdom.
sen.cmt: If "河内守護であった畠山氏" is translated literally, we end up with a sentence saying that a clan acted as a governor, which doesn't really make much sense in English. I assume it is the leader of the clan that holds this position. It's a little difficult to translate "本領安堵された" into meaningful English but I think the change I have made works.
sen.e: They were originally part of the Kusunoki clan, but after surrendering to the Hatayama clan, whose leader was the Shugo (military governor) for Kawachi Province, they became vassals of the Hatayama clan and were allowed to keep their main domain as their fiefdom.

sen.j: その子孫として戦国時代 (日本)前期に甲斐庄隆成、戦国時代後期に烏帽子形城城主でキリシタンであった甲斐庄兵右衛門正治の名が見える。
sen.e: Among the known descendants, there is Takanari KAINOSHO during the first half of Sengoku period (period of warring states) and Heiemon Masaharu KAINOSHO, who was the lord of eboshi (formal headwear for court nobles) Castle and Christian during the later half of Sengoku period.

Known descendants of the clan include Takanari KAINOSHO, who lived during the first half of the Sengoku period (period of warring states), and Heiemon Masaharu KAINOSHO, who was the lord of Eboshigata Castle and a Christian who lived during the later half of the Sengoku period.
sen.cmt: I think "烏帽子形城" is just the name of the castle here, isn't it? If so, there is no need to explain the meaning of "烏帽子".Eboshigata→Eboshigata-jo
sen.e: Known descendants of the clan include Takanari KAINOSHO, who lived during the first half of the Sengoku period (period of warring states), and Heiemon Masaharu KAINOSHO, who was the lord of Eboshigata-jo Castle and a Christian who lived during the later half of the Sengoku period.

sen.j: 正治は畠山家重臣で烏帽子形城城主であったが畠山氏没落に伴い、烏帽子形城を失い没落した。
sen.e: However, due to the fall of the Hatayama clan, Masaharu lost the Castle, which eventually led to his downfall.
Although Masaharu was a senior vassal of the Hatakeyama family and a lord of Eboshigata-jo Castle, due to the fall of the Hatayama clan, he lost the Castle, which eventually led to his downfall.
Although Masaharu was a senior vassal of the Hatakeyama family and a lord of Eboshigata-jo Castle, due to the fall of the Hatayama clan, he lost the Castle, which eventually led to his downfall.

sen.j: 流浪したがいつの頃からかは定かではないが徳川家康に仕える。
sen.e: After, Masaharu wandered Japan until he began serving Ieyasu TOKUGAWA from time unknown.
After that, Masaharu wandered Japan until he began serving Ieyasu TOKUGAWA from time unknown.
After that, Masaharu wandered Japan until he began serving Ieyasu TOKUGAWA from time unknown.

sen.j: また、その子、甲斐庄喜右衛門正房も徳川家康に仕え、御家人として家名が存続した。
sen.e: His child, Kiemon Masafusa KAINOSHO also served Ieyasu TOKUGAWA and their family name continued as gokenin (an immediate vasal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods).
His child, Kiemon Masafusa KAINOSHO also served Ieyasu TOKUGAWA and their family name continued as gokenin (an immediate vasal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods).
His child, Kiemon Masafusa KAINOSHO also served Ieyasu TOKUGAWA and their family name continued as gokenin (an immediate vasal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods).

sen.j: 大坂の陣では河内の地理に詳しいことから道案内をつとめ、加増を受けて旗本となった。
sen.e: Since he was familiar with thegeography of Kawachi, he assumed the positionas a guide during the Osaka no Jin (The Siege of Osaka), and and eventually promoted to hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu, which is a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)

Since he was familiar with the geography of Kawachi, he assumed the positionas a guide during the Osaka no Jin (The Siege of Osaka), and and eventually promoted to hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu, which is a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) with an increase in territory.
sen.cmt: スペースを挿入訳漏れを補足
sen.e: Since he was familiar with the geography of Kawachi, he assumed the positionas a guide during the Osaka no Jin (The Siege of Osaka), and and eventually promoted to hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu, which is a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) with an increase in territory.

sen.j: 一説によると、本能寺の変の際、堺市から三河国へ帰国する家康に同行した河内の土豪で、家康の警護をした恩賞として、旧領復帰（2,000石）と加増（2,000石）で4,000石の旗本になったともいう。
sen.e: According to a theory, it is also thought that Kiemonmasafusa was a local clan in Kawachi that was appointed as hatamoto of 4000 koku (2000 of them was the regain of the former territory and the rest 2000 was a raise) as a reward for having served as Ieyasu's guard.

According to a theory, it is also thought that Kiemon Masafusa KAINOSHO was a local clan in Kawachi that was appointed as hatamoto of 4000 koku (2000 of them was the regain of the former territory and the rest 2000 was a raise) as a reward for having served as Ieyasu's guard.

According to a theory, it is also thought that Kiemon Masafusa KAINOSHO was a local clan in Kawachi that was appointed as hatamoto of 4000 koku (2000 of them was the regain of the former territory and the rest 2000 was a raise) as a reward for having served as Ieyasu's guard.

sen.j: 正房の子、正述は長崎奉行をつとめ、その正述の子、飛騨守正親は勘定奉行、江戸南町奉行＜在任期間：延宝8年（1680年）8月30日～元禄3年（1690年）12月3日＞などをつとめるなど活躍した。
sen.e: Masahusa's child, Masanobu served as a Nagasaki bugyo (Nagasaki magistrate) and his child, Masachika HIDANOKAMI served as kanjo bugyo (commissioner of finance) and Edo Minamimachi Bugyo (Magistrate) (served from August 30, 1680 to December 3, 1690).

Masahusa's child, Masanobu served as a Nagasaki bugyo (Nagasaki magistrate) and his child, Masachika HIDANOKAMI served as kanjo bugyo (commissioner of finance) and Edo Minamimachi Bugyo (Magistrate) (served from August 30, 1680 to December 3, 1690).

Masahusa's child, Masanobu served as a Nagasaki bugyo (Nagasaki magistrate) and his child, Masachika HIDANOKAMI served as kanjo bugyo (commissioner of finance) and Edo Minamimachi Bugyo (Magistrate) (served from August 30, 1680 to December 3, 1690).

sen.j: また、同族で別系統に能登甲斐庄氏があり、甲斐庄駿河守家繁が能登畠山氏重臣として見える。
sen.e: The Noto Kainosho clan is one of the families that descended from the same family line; Ieshige KAINOSHO, Suruga no kami (the governor of Suruga Province) from this family served as a senior vassal to the Noto Hatakeyama clan.

The Noto Kainosho clan was part of the Kainosho clan, but from a different family line; Ieshige KAINOSHO, who was a member of this clan and held the position of Suruga no kami (the governor of Suruga Province), served as a senior vassal to the Noto Hatakeyama clan.

The Noto Kainosho clan was part of the Kainosho clan, but from a different family line; Ieshige KAINOSHO, who was a member of this clan and held the position of Suruga no kami (the governor of Suruga Province), served as a senior vassal to the Noto Hatakeyama clan.

sen.j: 河内国の畠山氏からの分家である能登畠山氏に、甲斐庄氏からも分家した一族が従っていたものと思われる。
sen.e: It is believed that this family branch of the K clan serve Noto Hatakeyama clan, also a branch family of Hayama clan from Kawachi Province.
It is believed that this family branch of the Kainosho clan serve Noto Hatakeyama clan, also a branch family of Hatakeyama clan from Kawachi Province.
It is believed that this family branch of the Kainosho clan serve Noto Hatakeyama clan, also a branch family of Hatakeyama clan from Kawachi Province.

sen.j: 甲斐庄正親は「八百屋お七悲恋物語」にも登場する南町奉行、甲斐庄飛騨守と同一人物である。
sen.e: Masachika KAINOSHO is the same person as Hidanokami KAINOSHO who appears in "Yaoya Oshichi (Greengrocer's Oshichi)'s story."
Masachika KAINOSHO is the same person as Hidanokami KAINOSHO, Minamimachi bugyo (magistrate), who appears in "Yaoya Oshichi (Greengrocer's Oshichi)'s story."
Masachika KAINOSHO is the same person as Hidanokami KAINOSHO, Minamimachi bugyo (magistrate), who appears in "Yaoya Oshichi (Greengrocer's Oshichi)'s story."

sen.j: また、同族として、旗本で美濃郡代（在任期間：天和 (日本)3年（1683年）～貞享2年（1685年））をつとめた甲斐庄正之がいる。
sen.e: Masayuki KAINOSHO is another person from the same family who served as a hatamoto and as a Minogundai (a magistrate of Mino region) from 1683 to 1885.
Masayuki KAINOSHO is another person from the same family who served as a hatamoto and as a Minogundai (a magistrate of Mino region) from 1683 to 1885.
Masayuki KAINOSHO is another person from the same family who served as a hatamoto and as a Minogundai (a magistrate of Mino region) from 1683 to 1885.

sen.j: 正親が南町奉行在職中であるので、その兄弟ではないかと推測されるが断定はできない。
sen.e: As this preiod is during the time of Masachika's tenure, it is conjectured that they could have been brother but there is no clear evidence to support this theory.

sen.j: 判明している人物を時系列で並べてあるが、必ずしも全てではない。

sen.j: 甲斐荘泰生→甲斐莊正晃 株式会社日本総合研究所システムコンサルティング部上席主任研究員。
sen.e: Taisei KAINOSHO (later changed his name to Masaaki KAINOSHO) is a senior researcher of the System Consulting department of Japan Research Institute, Ltd.

sen.j: 著書「エージェント・システム―コンピュータ代理人社会のゆくえ」など。

sen.j: 改名後、株式会社KAINOSHO（旧社名：ケイブレイン株式会社）代表取締役、著書「インナーブランディング」。
sen.e: After changing his name, he has become the president of KAINOSHO (former Keiburein) and the author of a book, 'Inner Branding.'

sen.j: 甲斐荘正恒 東京都立大学理学研究科化学専攻教授、日本核磁気共鳴学会会長。
sen.e: Masatsune Kainosho, professor of Chemistry at the Department Graduate School, Science and Engineering of Tokyo Metropolitan University and the president of the Japanese Society of Magnetic Resonance in Medicine.
sen.cmt: I am not sure if this is the correct information. The society's site does not say that he is the president: http://www.jsmrm.jp/modules/outline/index.php?content_id=2

sen.j: 甲斐荘敬司 株式会社ジャパンエナジー精製技術センター主任研究員、共著「白色LED照明システム技術の応用と将来展望」。
